review.title: A rational analysis of curiosity
review.abstract: We present a rational analysis of curiosity, proposing that people's curiosity is driven by seeking stimuli that maximize their ability to make appropriate responses in the future. This perspective offers a way to unify previous theories of curiosity into a single framework. Experimental results confirm our model's predictions, showing how the relationship between curiosity and confidence can change significantly depending on the nature of the environment.

sections.heading: Testing the model predictions
sections.text: This section describes the behavioral experiment conducted to test our model predictions, using two different scenarios - confidence sample and uniform sample - to assess whether people's curiosity is affected by changes in the relationship between need probability and confidence. In the confidence sample state, we created an environment in which need probability is related to confidence (Figure 1, Figure 1) and in the uniform sample condition, they were independent of each other (Figure 2, Figure 1). Based on our model predictions, we assume that there will be a reverse U-shaped relationship between trust and curiosity in the confidence condition, and that there will be a decreasing relationship in a uniform sample condition.

sections.heading: Participants
sections.text: We recruited 298 participants from Amazon Mechanical Turk. They earned $1.50 for participating with the option to earn an additional bonus of $0.80. Participants in the experiment were randomly assigned to one of two conditions: confidence sampling conditions (163 participants) and uniform sampling conditions (135 participants). Informed consent was obtained using a consent form approved by the Berkeley Institutional Review Board.

sections.heading: Stimuli
sections.text: The stimuli used in the experiment were 40 trivial questions on various topics taken directly from Experiment 1 in Kang et al. (2009). According to the authors, these questions were designed to measure curiosity about semantic knowledge and to elicit a number of levels of curiosity.

sections.heading: Procedure
sections.text: The experiment was divided into two phases - the main round and bonus round. The main round was used to elicit participants and measure curiosity for the right answer. Participants were rated on a scale of 1 to 7 and the confidence scale ranged from 0 to 100%. Following Kang et al's methodology, raw curiosity ratings were individually normalized and confidence on a scale of 0 to 1. The sequence of trivial questions was randomized for each participant.

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text: Curiosity is one of the hallmarks of human intelligence and crucial to scientific discoveries and inventions. Models of curiosity have previously explained human curiosity by linking it to various psychological factors such as novelty, information gap and learning progress. We have shown that these different models are all special cases of curiosity - depending on the environment, curiosity can be driven by each of these factors. In addition to the possibility of unifying earlier unambiguous mechanistic explanations of curiosity, our rational model explains human curiosity in different situations. Our results suggest that human curiosity is not only sensitive to the properties of stimuli, but is also influenced by the nature of the environment. When people are in an environment in which exposure is likely to be influenced, their curiosity is highest for stimuli of which they are moderately confident. On the other hand, when necessity is probability and exposure independent, then curiosity is highest for novel stimuli, i.e. stimuli in which people have little confidence.

Following Kang et al.’s methodology, the raw curiosity ratings were individually normalized and confidence was rescaled to range from 0 to 1. The order of trivia questions was randomized for each participant. Thus, the main round of the experiment followed the procedure of Kang et al.’s design closely. This part of the experiment took approximately 7-8 minutes to complete. After the main round, the bonus round began which consisted of two parts. In the first part, all 40 questions from the main round were shown one after another and participants could choose to reveal the answer to those questions. However, each time they chose to reveal an answer, they had to wait an extra 10 seconds for the next question to appear. Findings from Experiment 3 of Kang et al. (2009) showed that participants were more likely to spend time, to wait longer, for the answers that they were more curious about.
